text: Man I really wish we could (as a society) find a way to stop seeing rape as a sexual act. I don't even know how to make that possible but I wish it was.

replies.author: @ambriaashley3383
replies.text: We just have to keep repeating it, have to keep hammering them with facts, just repeat it & repeat it & correct the casual misinformation until they all get it through their heads: ‚ÄúRape is not about sex. It‚Äôs about power.‚Äù

replies.author: @akinyiomer4589
replies.text:
One thing that strikes me about society refusing to see rape, SA and abuse for how heinous it is is that the mindset & justifications of the attacker are just not believed to be as malignant and messed up as we know they are. Like, it's only people NOT already prone to victim-blaming or disbelieving victims that understood Cassie's testimony when it came out. 

Cause if you've understood that type of need for power in some way, you can put two, three, four & five together with Diddy's long history of treating his artists like shit and his random acts of violence towards people in the music industry. Those who know (mostly women let's be fair) know that that's a pattern of an angry, abusive man who _needs_ to feel power; _needs_ to crush people under his power. 

Most just look it his history like separate events "yeah I guess he was shady but isn't she just trying to get a cheque off him?" 

I think it's down to a mixture of a few things: the hangover of women aren't really people and women owe themselves to men for their gratification, sexual or service-based. Y'know standard toxic patriarchal society bullshit. 

But the second thing is more complicated: it is genuinely hard to wrap your mind around vicious acts if you're a well-adjusted person. Theres a reason why whenever we hear of a horrible bully, a murder, a mass shooting, a terrorist attack, we ask "why???"  Our empathy for our fellow man STOPS your brain from thinking that way most of  the time. It's distressing to even put yourself in the shoes of the attacker and go through their cognitive reasoning. It will leave you fucked up. 

And that's where a lot of abusers & r!pists get away with it IMO: none of them are ever honest, except to like-minded people, about how they truly think & feel in those situations.

Seriously think about it. I know a lot about DV & SA because of victim impact, victims stories etc. I cannot think of a single time, outside of an attacker flexing to fellow degenerates on a message board, that someone has come out and said "yeah and this is what that was like for me. That's why I did it. Here's what was going through my mind when i strangled this person." Its SILENCE. Because they KNOW their true rationale is heinous, so its always deflected or minimised or "well it was her fault for not listening to me" etc. 

I hope my argument is making some sense to someone.

replies.author: @Erinestrella71310
replies.text: Exactly- rape is a behavioral health issue, but no one talks about it. Even therapists.

replies.text:
@B1ackKingStar not in so specific a sense. But often, when an abuser gets exposed, there are people who come out and say "he never hurt me that way" and that's supposed to, somehow, take credibility away from the idea that this person is abusive. 

There was an example of this in Diddy's story, but I can't remember the name of the person who said it haha but they mention it in the video

replies.author: @codycat6
replies.text: ‚Äã‚Äã@B1ackKingStar very different situation but my own brother has said the "she wasn't like that to me" "maybe you need to work it out" to me about my mum's abuse towards me throughout my life (specifically ages 12 onwards). a lot more common than you think because people take their personal perspective as absolute truth.

replies.author: @B1ackKingStar
replies.text: @codycat6¬† I'm sorry to hear that your family was unreceptive to you and your feelings. I wish you nothing but love and support in your future.

replies.author: @codycat6

replies.author: @20xx-mm-dd
replies.text:
The confusion comes from the implicit essentialist idea that there are "good people" and "bad people" because they think "bad people" would always be bad and do bad things. When someone does something good the assumption is that they must be a "good person."

Edit I should say PART of the disconnect comes from that idea. There's lots of reasons why people ignore abuse against others.

author: @beck2494
text: I really appreciate this episode of Olay & Friends because there was an unspoken fear that arose in me when I saw how much emphasis was being placed on the sexual deviance of the freak offs. I didn't know if there was space in this conversation to say that coercing victims, whether or not they are paid to be there, is wrong and also "deviant" sexuality should not be criminalized. As I watch this I see it's actually hugely important to state both of these things because it is no coincidence that the victims involved exist on the fringes of society already because of their professions, race, gender express & identity, and/or drug usage. I love every episode you put out <3 <3

replies.author: @TubezThe1
replies.text:
Also, just because people may have been paid to be there doesn't mean that they were there willingly. Like, did we forget how many powerful men have paid victims for silence? Or the fact that he has a lot of these people on camera. 

Really the sexual deviancy thing has really bothered me, because the only people that truly can get away with shit like that are very powerful rich people, like diddy, or republicans, despite how much they want to deny that they even have sex in the first place. Like the way they're talking about it is giving priest Stonewall riot energy, where cops were just busting into queer bars and harassing people for being there, only in this case, many of the people in charge have the cops in their pockets. And I really don't like how they're trying to make this about sex when it's not. What happened there was not sex. It was not consensual. Many of the victims were minors. They weren't sex workers. From the people I've talked to and things are read from them, No professional sex worker would ever work with a man like Diddy. 

But instead of all of that, people want to focus on baby oil, and lube, and if he had sex with a man. They're so goddamn unserious and they're the ones who always get to be heard the most because other people are just as stupid and unserious as them.

author: @Philluminati0n
text: I definitely agree that it seems like the victims' suffering is taking a backseat to the spectacle, but I also think that's a symptom of American culture and just how American media works.  Reputable stories about Diddy abusing/threatening people have been coming out for years, but none of them seem to stick in the media cycle.  A few headlines about lube/baby oil though, and now all anyone is talking about is Diddy's indictment.  Like to the point where even gaming channels I follow are making vids about it.

author: @seese9456
text: Honestly, the cultural deconstruction of patriarchy is a long and intensive process, which goes beyond Diddy's prosecution and sentencing. For the moment, I think it's important for the victims to GET THEIR JUSTICE, and Diddy needs to deal with whatever that looks like. People need to realize there's no such thing as a "perfect victim" and that powerful men HAVE CONNECTIONS WITH THE LAW. Hence, we need to audit them and their "friends" more often, whilst also framing these people as a cautionary tale of how absolute power corrupts absolutely.

author: @BellamyJay
text:
Really glad to see yall talking about this.

One of the things I think that's missed when talking about the lube/baby oil because of how people are is what it represents from an evidentiary standpoint. I'm sure they have other indications of this but having worked as a paralegal for multiple prosecutors the things I think that aren't being communicated are

1. It shows intent to continue this behavior. You don't have that much lube if you don't intend to continue the same things you were up to (we know this without the lube but the lube can help prove it in court I think).

2. He didn't get that much lube by himself.

author: @A-Saxy-Bard
text:
Very very good video. The discussions around power and the criminal system were really thought provoking. 

Like, how do we construct a system that supports survivors while at the same time  perpetrators are held accountable and able to be rehabilitated  given the opportunity to make a meaningful change. 

I also agree that there needs to be more discussion around how men are raised to view power and sexuality, and the ways media can influence that. It kinda says something about the mediascape we live in where Zuko in avatar the last airbender presents one of  morr realistic depictions of interrogatinng ones own role in perpetuating harm. Where its a slow and often arduous process and not a singular act of self sacrificing redemption. 
I think media presents one potential way to more proactively introduce the tools one needs to understand the harm they can cause others and themselves. It has to be done in tandem with interpersonal and  community discussions around the "why"s yall discussed towards the end of the video.

author: @cierracruz5218
text: I think it would be good to discuss what trauma(s), mental health concerns, and limiting beliefs may have drawn people like Cassie, Usher, and Dawn Richard‚Äôs (any potential or known victims of Diddy) to him, and kept them around him long enough to be roped into his depravity, as that would help the rest of us avoid this with toxic people. We have to remember that there‚Äôs no correlation between violent behavior and trauma or mental health problems. Even if Diddy has his own trauma, committing acts of physical and sexual violence is always a personal choice. The ones with mental health issues are far more often the victims in the situation. I just don‚Äôt want the notion that this kind of depravity can be prevented if people are raised better or something.  Diddy is one part of a larger societal issue, but he is the only one responsible for what he did.

replies.author: @olurinatti
replies.text: We don‚Äôt know Cassie, Usher, Dawn or any of Diddy‚Äôs victims personally to be able to speak to what their traumas or mental health concerns are or how it drew them to Diddy, and I think it would be wildly irresponsible for us to speculate any of that.

replies.author: @cierracruz5218
replies.text: I agree üòä just being constructive. We don‚Äôt know Diddy personally either. My point is that it‚Äôs irresponsible to speculate how trauma may have turned Diddy into who he is, which is your section ‚ÄúThe Humanization of Diddy‚Äù. It implies a connection between trauma and perpetrating violence. The connection is between trauma and going on to survive violence.

author: @justhearmeout3959
text:
What about to protect? Shouldn't that be a point of prison as well? 

This is actually one of the things that makes it hard for me to wrap my head around abolition, tbh, although I probably just don't understand it well enough. One thing prison does is protects past, current, and potential future victims.

replies.author: @olurinatti
replies.text: Prison does not do that. You‚Äôre confusing what you‚Äôd like prison to be and what it is. Putting people in prison and exposing them to violence, sexual abuse and torture only guarantees more violence and crime when those people inevitably return to their communities.

replies.author: @justhearmeout3959
@akinyiomer4589
replies.text:
‚Äã@olurinatti I'm sorry this doesn't really make sense to me. You say that expecting one of the purposes of prison to be protection of society (current, past and future potential victims) from the offender is an idealistic position. So erroneously idealistic that you even posit that imprisoning people is that will cause a violent offender to get even more violent if and when released back into their communities. 

But your argument fails to see how overly-idealistic the abolitionist movement requires people to be.

Diddy, like many other abuse perpetrators before him - did not need _any_ help in being violent and abusive; in fact from the sounds of the civil and criminal suits against him he was damn right creative in his execution of violence. Are we expected to believe given all the pain & fear he put people through, if he served time, that somehow the levels of dysfunction he's gonna be subjected to are soooo great that we should put his needs over and above his victims who deserve justice? That what he'll experience as an inmate will be at the level of bullshit he put people through? 

And if that's the case and you're fine with that, then let's consider the next step. We know that any system isn't fair until it is applied wholly and equally across society. The justice system is currently unfair because it is not applied wholly and equally across all of society. But if were more equal, and we chose the prison-abolitionist way; when we get cases like white cops murdering black and brown people with impunity for fun and for sport - that prison-free justice system would have to apply to them too. So would we be happy saying calmly, to the families of George Floyd and everyone who suffered the same fate as him "well hey listen we don't want to subject the offender to more violence".  Because now we're getting awfully close to what these police departments have been trying to placate us with for years "no don't worry, we're very sorry for what happened but we're using this as a learning opportunity". That's how empty and devoid of justice it would feel to not just me but I think many others. 

The problem is with talking about criminal and rehabilitative justice from a purely ideological point of view is that it ignores the reality of human nature. We get the best progressive, most humane structures when we strive to give people the chance to be better but we also recognise that overly-idealistic or moralistic policy prescriptions can be damaging in the long run. That's one of the things that pro-purity culture and anti-sex education advocates struggle to understand. For them all you have to do is "be moral" and any consequences as a result of your moral failings are yours. 

That's one of the reasons why the architect of the Prohibition Era failed in his overall vision. He was the son of a violent alcoholic and rightfully had trauma surrounding it. He thought that "if we just do away with this, all will be fixed" ... and well, history and social science showed us how wrong he was. 

The same I think is very much true for the abolitionist movement I'm sorry to say. Just because the criminal justice system doesn't function ideally at all today, does not mean we mindlessly tear it all down without greater, nuanced thought of the consequences. Restorative justice between SA/r4pe victims and their attackers was intended by its architects to be a "humanistic" approach to right the wrongs of SA abuse, but all it did was force victims into terrible positions of being made to minimise the effects of what happened.

author: @r.walker7986
text: Cassie's "lawsuit" was created to push them to settle, it was never meant to go to court. Those kinds of lawsuits are written to be the most embarrassing and inflammatory to force a high profile person to settle to save their image. It has never been actively challenged or tested for truth so while it (as intended) may seem bad, that does not mean she can prove everything, that aside, it does not mean they will be able to meet the burden of truth with trying to turn a sloppy record label into a crime syndicate becasue he called friends at the label and asked then to ask her to call him back when she left(coincidentally proving she could come and go as she pleased) She also included in her statement that he had her pick out and contact the sex workers which might mean the paper trail leads to her. Bottom line, having enough probable cause to get an indictment does not mean that when it all goes to trial they can offer key witnesses more than can be offered by Diddy for thier silence or playing dumb on the stand. He has a lot of money and involving the label has probably created a bidding war for silence among employees, etc. so this will be interesting... We know the sex workers are not going to gom against him... Its worth it to dump it all on cassie, they would be set for life...
